articles.title: A Vast Swathe of The Arctic Has Turned Into a Carbon Emitter
articles.author: David Nield
articles.summary: More than a third of Arctic-Boreal Zone (ABZ) is emitting CO2 rather than capturing it. The same thing is happening in parts of the Amazon Rainforest. Wildfires are becoming more frequent and impactful in the ABZ. Nearly half of the carbon stored in soil on the planet is thought to be in this region.

articles.title: How do West Virginia's birds survive sub-zero temperatures?
articles.author: Sam Gorski
articles.summary: West Virginia's winter weather is unpredictable. Some birds migrate south during the winter, while others stay in the state. The main reason for migration is food. Climate change is affecting bird migration patterns in recent years. Some species are being found further north than they used to.

articles.title: Climate change made ferocious LA wildfires more likely: study
articles.author: New Albany Gazette
articles.summary: Human-driven climate change set the stage for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires, according to the U.S. National Institute of Water Resources. There is an overlap between flammable drought conditions and powerful Santa Ana winds, which is fueling the fires.

articles.title: Climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of conditions fueling California wildfires, study finds
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent devastating Southern California wildfires. Global warming boosted the likelihood of high fire weather conditions in this month's fires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade super strong Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn that followed two wet years, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed 29 people.

articles.title: Conditions that fueled L.A. fires were 35% more likely because of climate change, scientists find
articles.author: NBC News
articles.summary: The hot, dry and windy conditions that preceded the Southern California fires were 35% more likely because of climate change, according to a new report. The report was released by the Center for Climate Change Research and Policy.    iReport.com:

articles.title: Trump administration's surprise federal funding freeze hits Medicaid while raising havoc and sowing confusion across Illinois
articles.author: Effingham Daily News
articles.summary: The administration announced it was freezing potentially dangerous levels of federal funding for the project. It comes hours after Republican President Donald Trump's administration announced that it would freeze potentially harmful levels of funding for a project. The project is called "further freezing potentially harmful federal funds".

articles.title: Study says climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the hot, dry and windy conditions that fanned the flames of the recent devastating Southern California wildfires, a scientific study found. The study was published in the journal "Climatology" and is based on data from the IPCC.

articles.title: Study says climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Study says climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense. Hot, dry and windy conditions that fanned the flames of the recent devastating Southern California wildfires were the result of human-caused climate change, according to the study.

articles.title: New Climate Attribution Study Shows that Big Oil Set the Stage for LA Fires (Public Citizen Inc)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: New climate change study shows that Big Oil set the stage for the Los Angeles fires. The study claims that climate change contributed to the hot, dry, and windy conditions that caused the fires. It also increased the chances that the sparks that started the fires would turn into raging conflagrations that destroyed many lives and homes.

articles.title: Climate change primed LA to burn — catastrophically
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: There were wildfires in Los Angeles earlier this month. Scientists say climate change has worsened the blazes. Drought conditions are more frequently pushing into winter, increasing the chance a fire will break out during Santa Ana winds, which can turn small ignitions into deadly infernos.

articles.title: L.A. fire conditions made 35 per cent more likely thanks to climate change, researchers say
articles.author: Inayat Singh
articles.summary: Fires devastated neighbourhoods in Los Angeles, killing 28 people and burning over 16,000 homes and buildings. New analysis suggests the conditions that led to January's wildfires were 35 per cent more likely because of human-fuelled climate change. The study was carried out by a team of 32 researchers from the World Weather Attribution (WWA) group.

articles.title: New export records for Aussie goatmeat
articles.author: Staff Reporters
articles.summary: Australia's goatmeat industry is growing on the back of favourable weather and expansion of processing plants. For the calendar year, exports smashed the previous Australian record of 35,778 tonnes shipped weight (swt), hitting 51,488 tonnes swt. Victoria remains the largest processing state, accounting for 44% of all Australian goatmeat, followed by Queensland at 27%, and then NSW at 26%.

articles.title: Climate change made the deadly Los Angeles wildfires more likely. And, the worst is yet to come
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: There were 29 wildfires that killed 29 people in California this month due to climate change. The blazes were made more likely due to warming caused by the burning of oil, gas and coal. Global warming is 2.6 degrees Celsius (4.7 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than preindustrial levels. After months without rain, Southern California saw rain this week.

articles.title: Study says climate change made conditions that fed Los Angeles wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: A new study confirms that human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires. The prolonged dry season, extended by 23 days, combined with the intensifying Santa Ana winds created a dangerous tinderbox. The study paints a sobering picture, stating that the world warming by 1.3 degrees celsius could dramatically increase the frequency of these deadly fire-prone conditions.

articles.title: Conditions that fueled L.A. fires were more likely due to climate change, scientists find
articles.author: Evan Bush
articles.summary: Climate change increased the likelihood of the extreme conditions that allowed the recent fires to roar across the Los Angeles area, an international group of scientists said Tuesday. The fires started during a ferocious windstorm and after almost no rain had fallen in greater Los Angeles since the spring, killing at least 29 people and torching more than 16,000 buildings.

articles.title: Conditions that fueled L.A. fires were 35% more likely because of climate change, scientists find

articles.title: Climate change made devastating LA fires more likely, scientists say
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: The hot dry conditions behind the wildfires are expected to occur every 17 years in today's climate. Global warming has warmed 1.3C since pre-industrial times. Wildfires are 35% more likely to occur than in a world without global warming and 6% more intense.

articles.summary: According to a recent report, human-caused climate change has increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent wildfires in Southern California by 35% and 6%. However, scientists acknowledge the complexities and uncertainties involved in attributing specific fires to climate change. The fires killed at least 29 people and destroyed thousands of homes.

articles.title: LA fires made worse by climate change, say scientists
articles.author: Matt McGrath
articles.summary: Climate change was a major factor behind the hot, dry weather that gave rise to the devastating LA fires. It made those weather conditions about 35% more likely, according to World Weather Attribution. 30 people have died and more than 10,000 homes destroyed in the fires that broke out in early January.

articles.title: Kenya, Burundi, Tanzania brace for heavy rainfall: ICPAC
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Kenya, Burundi and Tanzania will receive more rainfall than usual in the coming week, leading to floods. The most affected countries are expected to be South Sudan, Uganda, Tanzania, Kenya, Somalia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia and Sudan.

articles.title: Global Warming Set the Stage for Los Angeles Fires
articles.author: Bob Berwyn
articles.summary: Today's climate is 2.3 degrees Fahrenheit (1.3 Celsius) warmer than the 1850-1900 pre-industrial average. Global warming made the recent fires around Los Angeles 35 times more likely to occur. The series of five major fires started January 7 and were mostly contained by January 28. At least 28 people died and more than 16,000 structures were damaged.

articles.title: Atomic ‘Doomsday Clock' edges closer to midnight
articles.summary: Atomic scientists moved their Doomsday Clock closer to midnight on Tuesday (January 28). They cited Russian nuclear threats, the invasion of Ukraine, tensions in other hot spots, military applications of artificial intelligence, and climate change as factors underlying the risks of global catastrophe. "Every second of delay in reversing course increases the probability of global disaster," said Daniel Holz, the chair of the Science and Security Board at the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists.

articles.title: Alert: Study says climate change made extreme fire conditions that fed California blazes more likely
articles.summary: Study says climate change made extreme fire conditions that fed California blazes more likely due to climate change, according to the study. The study was published in the journal "Climatology" by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.   .

articles.title: Climate change made devastating LA fires more likely, scientists say
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: Wildfires in Los Angeles killed at least 28 people and destroyed more than 10,000 homes, racking up billions in costs and leaving thousands of people homeless. Hot, dry and windy conditions that drove the fires were about 35% more likely due to global warming, mainly due to burning fossil fuels. Global warming has warmed 1.3C since pre-industrial times.

articles.title: 'Stay hydrated': heatwave conditions linger over Northern Tablelands
articles.author: Jacob McMaster
articles.summary: Temperatures are predicted to climb above the forecast maximums on Wednesday across Armidale and vast parts of the Northern Tablelands, including the Northern Territory.      .   in the Northern Territories, in the state of Victoria, in particular.

articles.title: Experts call for united action on draft climate change law in Africa
articles.author: John Ameh
articles.summary: Experts and stakeholders are calling on African leaders to pass the draft model climate change law to speed up efforts in tackling the impact of climate change on the continent. The law seeks to promote sustainable development by upholding the principles of the UNFCCC. It establishes a comprehensive legal framework for climate change mitigation, adaptation and resilience building across African nations. Only a few African countries have passed the law so far.

articles.title: Pembroke, Arnprior, Carleton Place, Smiths Falls, Perth, Renfrew, Kemptville under winter weather travel advisory
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: Winter weather travel advisory issued for Pembroke, Arnprior, Carleton Place, Smiths Falls, Perth, Renfrew, Kemptville and surrounding areas on Tuesday afternoon. Snowfall amounts of four to eight centimetres are expected Tuesday night and into Wednesday morning.

articles.title: Plymouth resident says birds continue to die of suspected bird flu outbreak
articles.summary: Bird flu is suspected to be killing birds at Billington Sea in Plymouth on Monday, Jan. 27, 2025. A dead Canada goose lies there. Bird flu strikes more birds there on the same day. A dying swan sits on the ice near some dead waterfowl.

articles.title: Plymouth resident says birds continue to die of suspected bird flu outbreak
articles.summary: Plymouth resident says birds continue to die of suspected bird flu outbreak. Bird flu is suspected to be killing birds at Billington Sea in Plymouth on Monday, Jan. 27, 2025. Avid birdwatcher Colleen Vissa takes photos of some of the birds near her home.

articles.title: Backlash after council votes for 40 per cent rate hike
articles.summary: The Northern Beaches Council in Sydney voted to increase rates by 40 per cent across three years, which has angered many people. It narrowly passed by a vote of 3-2, but is under fire for the increase in rates. It is estimated to be around $1.5 billion a year.

articles.title: The political & social cost of climate crisis
articles.author: Shyam Saran
articles.summary: The political and social consequences of unabated climate change and irreversible global warming are less understood and appreciated. They are already changing societies. Climate change is exacerbating income and wealth inequalities. It is changing weather patterns and vast areas of productive farmland. It triggers large population movements within countries and across borders. Migration issue has become an instrument of political mobilisation through fear of the "outsider". Populism is an expression of this pathology.

articles.title: Building a resilient climate future
articles.author: Charika Channuntapipat
articles.summary: Thailand is unprepared for the financial fallout of climate change. The 2011 floods caused $54 billion baht in damage, but only 25% of the losses were covered by disaster insurance. Vietnam and Indonesia have set clear budgets and plans for climate adaptation. Thailand lacks concrete budgets for its national adaptation plan. Businesses are reluctant to invest due to stagnant economy and limited access to adaptation funds.

articles.title: Africa splitting in two as East African Rift paves the way for a new ocean
articles.summary: East Africa is undergoing a monumental geological transformation. The Somali Plate is pulling away from the Nubian Plate. The Indian Ocean is expected to flood the rift valley, creating a new ocean. This transformation will redraw Africa's geography and have profound implications for trade, ecosystems, and local economies.

articles.title: The Government is missing a chance
articles.summary: The Green Building Council says the Government's proposal to simplify insulation standards does not address the growing issue of overheating new builds. The council's chief executive Andrew Eagles says there are increasing reports of new builds being saunas in summer with indoor temperatures as high as 50 degrees.

articles.title: Finishing off an exceptionally dry and cold January
articles.author: Riley Smith
articles.summary: A large arctic air mass has made its way through much of the United States recently. This caused subzero temperatures in Iowa and brought snow to the Southeast. This January was the second driest on record for Iowa, but the temperatures have warmed up already.

articles.title: Ocean Warming Has Quadrupled Since 1980s, Study Shows
articles.author: Dashel Pierson
articles.summary: The ocean surface has been rising in temperature at unprecedented levels. In the 1980s, data showed a 0.06 degrees Celsius per decade rise; today, the data shows the temperatures are rising 0.27 degrees per decade. It is plausible that the ocean temperature increase seen over the past 40 years will be exceeded in the next 20 years.

articles.title: Dutch Parliament Supports Climate Aid for CAS Islands and Pushes for Child Benefits in Caribbean Netherlands
articles.author: Vordev
articles.summary: The Dutch Parliament has approved a motion by Raoul White advocating increased climate aid for the CAS islands (Curaçao, Aruba, and Sint Maarten). Only PVV, BBB, Forum for Democracy, and JA21 voted against the motion.

articles.title: La Tierra está cada vez más cerca de la destrucción por cambio climático, el nuclear, pandemias e IA
articles.summary: Earth is moving closer to destruction, a science-oriented advocacy group says. It advanced its famous "Doomsday Clock" to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been to the date of the end of the world, it says. The group is concerned about climate change.

articles.title: Arctic ice melt: Rising seas and underwater marvels
articles.author: Justyna Waliszewska
articles.summary: Antarctica's ice sheet contains 60% of the world's fresh water and is melting at an alarming rate. The ocean melts the lower layers of the ice sheet, causing them to melt and retreat, which raises sea levels. New computer simulations and underwater robots have acquired new data about the environment beneath the ice shelves.

articles.title: ‘Expect hazardous winter driving conditions': Peterborough County, Kawartha Lakes, Northumberland under weather advisories
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued weather alerts for much of southern Ontario. An Alberta clipper is bringing snow to the area on Tuesday, Jan. 28. The Peterborough-Kawartha areas are under a winter weather travel advisory. They are expected to get some of the highest snowfall totals in the province.

articles.title: Peace Coalition of Southern Illinois to hst monthly vigil on Saturday,, join Rally for Peace in Gaza on Sunday
articles.author: THE SOUTHERN STAFF
articles.summary: The Peace Coalition of Southern Illinois will hold the Monthly Peace and Justice Vigil from noon to 1 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 1, at the corner of Main Street and Illinois Avenue. The group will join the weekly Rally for Peace in Gaza on Sunday, February 2, to celebrate the fragile ceasefire.

articles.title: Outer space's crucial role in tackling climate change and global health
articles.summary: Air pollution is the biggest health threat facing humanity. Satellites and remote sensing data provide evidence of climate change and its effects. Space for Climate Observatory coordinates the efforts of space agencies and organizations in addressing climate change. Space can play a preventive role through computer modeling to predict climate variations and develop early warning systems for extreme weather events. Remote sensing is crucial for monitoring desertification and supporting climate resilience and clean energy solutions.

articles.title: Tanzania's Climate-Health Crisis: Risks, Impacts, and Resilience Strategies
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: Tanzania is at the crossroads of climate change and public health crises. Rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and increasingly frequent extreme weather events are magnifying existing health challenges and introducing new risks. The report draws attention to the alarming rise of vector-borne diseases, particularly malaria and dengue fever. It also highlights the growing burden of air pollution.

articles.title: U.S. States Where Housing Markets Are About to Crash
articles.author: Jessica Garrison
articles.summary: Housing market in Texas may be facing headwinds due to fluctuating buyer demand, oversupply of new housing developments, and broader economic uncertainties. Texas's vulnerability to natural disasters, including hurricanes and flooding, poses additional risks to the state's housing market.

articles.title: Students impacted by Hurricane Helene can apply for NCCF Disaster Relief and Resilience Scholarship
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene negatively impacted students' ability to pay for higher education in western North Carolina. North Carolina Community Foundation's Disaster Relief and Resilience Scholarship is open to undergraduate and graduate students from 29 counties attending two- or four-year colleges and universities. There is no cost to apply.

articles.title: ‘Doomsday Clock' moves closer to midnight amid threats of climate change, nuclear war, pandemics, AI
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: A science-oriented advocacy group says the Earth is moving closer to destruction and is on the verge of destruction. It's a matter of time before the Earth destroys itself, they say. It will get worse before it gets better, according to the group.

articles.summary: A science-oriented advocacy group says the Earth is moving closer to destruction. It was originally published on January 28, 2025 at 11:40 AM MST and has been updated to reflect the new date. It is no longer available to be subscribed to.

articles.title: Running AMOC (Member Post)
articles.author: Occupant CDN
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation moderates the climate of Western and Northern Europe. London, England is at the same latitude as Calgary, AB, Canada (North of Toronto). Calgary gets snow whereas London gets rain. An ice age would disrupt the normal weather patterns.

articles.title: Blue carbon ecosystems critical against climate change
articles.author: Meena Janardhan
articles.summary: Marine ecosystems, or blue carbon ecosystems, play important roles in supporting biodiversity and providing livelihoods. Blue carbon refers to carbon that is captured from the atmosphere and stored in marine and coastal ecosystems like seagrass meadows, mangroves and tidal marshes. These ecosystems are carbon removal powerhouses, storing up to five times more carbon per area than tropical forests. They also function as a protective barrier against extreme weather events.

articles.title: HEALTH SURVEY: Residents stressed by hurricane aftermath
articles.summary: Survey of Charlotte County residents shows growing need for relief in post-hurricane conditions. 11% of respondents said they had little access to healthy food or clean water in 2020, according to the survey of nearly 1,300 Charlotte County citizens.

articles.title: World on the Edge: Doomsday Clock Ticks Ever Closer
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has been moved to 89 seconds to midnight. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists cites Russian nuclear threats, climate change, and military AI applications as significant concerns. Daniel Holz, chair of the Bulletin's Science and Security Board, calls for international cooperation to prevent a global catastrophe.

articles.title: Houtman Abrolhos Islands visitors urged to take caution during seabird breeding season after recent survey
articles.summary: Houtman Abrolhos Islands visitors urged to take caution during seabird breeding season after recent survey. The area is home to a large number of seabirds, especially in the breeding season, when the birds are active.

articles.title: Another Ocean Warming Scare: Bad Models, Bad Data, and a Clear Agenda
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Merchant et al. claim that sea surface temperature (SST) is accelerating at an alarming rate due to Earth's Energy Imbalance (EEI). Their solution is immediate and severe reductions in fossil fuel use. The data they use to reach this conclusion is riddled with uncertainty.

articles.title: Careful what you ask for!
articles.author: John Jefferson
articles.summary: There was a week of sub-freezing temperatures in Texas. The cold weather helped some species more than hurt others. Some geese may have left for warmer climes in Mexico. All duck and sandhill crane seasons are now closed. The goose season in the East Zone is closed except for light geese (snow geese, blue geese and Ross' geese). Light geese can be hunted in the West Zone until Feb. 2. Quail season closes on Feb. 23.

articles.title: P.E.I. farmers adapt to climate change with new plan
articles.author: Yutaro Sasaki
articles.summary: The P.E.I. Federation of Agriculture held its 84th annual general meeting at Red Shores Racetrack and Casino in Charlottetown on Jan. 24. There, the organization's climate change adaptation plan was presented. The federation is assessing the potential risks from climate change for farmers across Prince Edward Island.

articles.title: Chiuluan 2 reaches Botswana
articles.summary: Amur Falcons (Falco amurensis) are on their annual migration from Siberia, China and Russia. Chiuluan 2, named after a village in Manipur's Tamenglong district, arrived in Botswana on Monday. The other Amur falcon, Gwangram, has not been transmitting signals since December 13.

articles.title: 2025 ‘Doomsday Clock'
articles.author: Abc Audio
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has been reset to 89 seconds before midnight. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved the clock one second closer to midnight because of the increase in nuclear risk, climate change, biological threats, and advances in disruptive technologies like artificial intelligence. The last two years, the clock stayed at 90 seconds to midnight.

articles.title: Dangerous cold across the land
articles.author: Ned Rozell
articles.summary: The map shows the coldest temperatures found in each state's period of recorded records. Alaska's coldest temperature on record was minus 80 degrees F on January 23, 1971, as shown on the graphic below.      .   i

articles.title: Climate change has direct impact on military power and operations, MPs warned
articles.summary: Armida Van Rij, head of the Europe Programme at Chatham House, was giving evidence to the Defence Select Committee. She warned that climate change has a direct impact on the UK and its European allies' ability to project power. She also said it could also result in a humanitarian disaster response that would alter training schedules.

articles.title: The Rate Of Ocean Surface Warming Has Quadrupled Since Satellite Measurements Began
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: Oceans are getting warmer at a rate of 0.27°C a decade. For 450 days between April 2023 and July 2024, sea temperatures averaged 0.18°C (0.32°F) degrees higher than they had ever been before. The previous extreme El Niño was in 1997-98. The rapid acceleration caused almost half of the extreme temperatures.

articles.title: Okaloosa County to host public meeting on flood risks and mitigation
articles.author: Northwest Florida Daily News
articles.summary: Okaloosa County and Jacobs Engineering will hold a public meeting for the Vulnerability Assessment Project on Feb. 10 from 5:30 to 7 p.m. in the Training Room of the Okalosa County Administrative Building at 1250 Eglin Parkway. The event will focus on future flood mitigation strategies and the potential impacts of flood events on the community.

articles.title: Seasonal temperatures continue to warm
articles.author: Rich Segal
articles.summary: Summer, fall, winter and spring are getting warmer. Winter is the warmest season in the eastern half of the U.S., but it's scattered in the western half. Anchorage, Fairbanks and Juneau, Alaska, and Honolulu, Hawaii had more winters warming faster than the other three seasons.

articles.title: Grande Prairie beats temperature record on Monday
articles.author: Erika Rolling
articles.summary: Grande Prairie reached 7.2 degrees Celsius on January 27, breaking the previous record set back in 1984 of 6.9 degrees Celsius. The average maximum daily temperature for January in Grande Prairie is -3.3 degrees Celsius and 2025 has started out unseasonable warmer than usual. Snow is forecast for the Peace Region by the weekend with lows of -20 degrees Celsius or greater.

articles.title: Heat-related deaths in Malta could triple by 2095 without climate action, study warns
articles.summary: Malta's heat-related deaths could triple by the end of the century if global warming is not tackled. In the summer of 2023, Malta recorded 80 excess deaths due to heatwaves and power outages. The report identifies Malta as the "most affected country" in Europe. Eastern Spain, Southern France, and Italy are singled out as particularly vulnerable regions.

articles.title: Great Lakes ice cover expanded rapidly in past week
articles.summary: The Arctic air over the Great Lakes last week caused a surge in ice concentration for most of them. Strong winds pushed the ice out into open water and pushed it down into the lake water. The general ice cover direction is toward average ice cover in the next few weeks. The Great Lakes ice cover will continue to grow, but probably at a much slower pace.

articles.title: Climate Displacement Is Also a Health Crisis
articles.author: Jayasree K. Iyer
articles.summary: Climate-induced migration poses both direct and indirect threats to public health. Pharmaceutical companies must play a pivotal role in addressing this crisis and strengthening global health resilience. They should help deliver medicines to vulnerable communities in remote areas by revamping their supply-chains. They must invest in research and development to create vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics targeting climate-sensitive diseases.

articles.title: ‘Doomsday Clock' moves closer to midnight amid threats of climate change, nuclear war, pandemics, AI
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has advanced its famous Doomsday Clock to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been to the end of the world. It cites threats such as climate change, proliferation of nuclear weapons, instability in the Middle East, pandemics and artificial intelligence in military operations.

articles.title: Climate change disrupts stork migration patterns in Turkey
articles.author: Abdulsalam Akinci
articles.summary: Global warming has changed the migration habits of white storks in the Tigris Valley in Turkey's southeastern city of Diyarbakir (Amed). Storks have always followed a migratory route through Africa, Europe and Asia. Anatolia has become a permanent home for many of these birds.

articles.summary: People in Barrow-in-Furness are at the highest risk of cancer compared to the rest of the North West. Morecambe Bay area has the highest rate of common cancers compared with the average rates for the whole North West or the whole region.

articles.title: Agricultural output may have contracted in 2024
articles.author: The Freeman
articles.summary: The value of agricultural output in the Philippines may have declined by more than 1% in 2024. El Niño and La Niña adversely affected the sector. The El Niño weather event brought below-normal rainfall conditions, dry spells and droughts that affected the overall harvest during the year. The second half of the year, the Philippines experienced a series of storms that brought heavy rains and caused flooding. African Swine Fever (ASF) and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza or bird flu continue to affect the production in livestock and poultry sectors.

articles.title: Climate change made ferocious LA wildfires more likely: study
articles.author: Apu GOMES
articles.summary: Human-driven climate change set the stage for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires, according to an analysis published Tuesday. The study concluded that the fire-prone conditions fueling the blazes were approximately 35 percent more likely due to global warming caused by burning fossil fuels.

articles.title: Ducks on ice
articles.summary: Temperatures reached 20 degrees and below in the region the night before. A flock of ducks meander over the frozen surface of a pond in Lewiston, Washington, on Monday morning. The temperature was 20 degrees below zero in the area the previous night.
